Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for DAMOP2015 for US Students -The Conference is being held June 8-12, 2015 at the Greater Columbus Convention Center in Columbus, Ohio.
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides travel support for student participation in the 46th Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (APS-DAMOP) to be held June 8-12, 2015 in Columbus, Ohio. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities). The Conference has grown in recent years and attracts over one-thousand participants. Covering all the major areas of atomic, molecular and optical physics, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. In addition, a one-day graduate student symposium in conjunction with the conference has been organized to introduce students to cutting-edge topics in atomic, molecular, and optical physics. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

STUDENT TRAVEL SUPPORT FOR THE 2015 DAMOP MEETING OF THE AMERICAN PHYSICAL SOCIETY

NSF supported 24 students to attend the 46th Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (APS-DAMOP) held June 8-12, 2015 at the Greater Columbus Convention Center in Columbus, Ohio. The DAMOP Conference has grown in recent years and attracts over one thousand participants. The Conference is an official meeting of the American Physical Society with a total budget exceeding $300,000. Support is needed to ensure the participation of a large and diverse group of researchers, and to help foster the interchange of scientific information among young scientists. Because of its influence on the productivity and up-to-date awareness of individual investigators, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States.

Because of its influence on the productivity and up-to-date awareness of individual investigators, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical (AMO) physics in the United States.  It is particularly important that younger members of our AMO community be able to attend and learn about the cutting-edge work occurring throughout the community.  76 student travel awards were allocated in 2015 in the amount of $500 each; funds for 24 such awards (totaling $12000) was provided by NSF.

 Further background

 The Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics of the APS is the primary professional society for most American atomic, molecular, and optical (AMO) physicists. The meeting embraces quantum optics, quantum information science, atom optics, strong-field phenomena, photoionization, Rydberg systems, optical lattices, Bose-Einstein condensation, cooling and trapping, attosecond science, collision physics, precision measurements, time and frequency standards, and related research. Both experimental and theoretical research areas are represented in proportions reflecting their national representation. The meeting highlights cutting edge atomic, molecular, and optical science from the United States and key results from the international community. The proceedings of the meeting are published in the Bulletin of the American Physical Society and are available on the World Wide Web.

The Conference is a very important vehicle for communication among active scientists in the field. It is a working conference, participation in which is highly important for active research scientists involved in the field if they are to remain truly abreast of current research activities and new developments. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. Because of its influence on the productivity and up-to-date awareness of individual investigators, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States.

Ongoing support is needed to ensure the participation of a large and diverse group of researchers, including those who may otherwise be unable to attend without the support from this grant. Grants such as that provided by NSF help to foster the interchange of scientific information among young scientists. An initial presentation at a DAMOP meeting is often a landmark event in the career of a young scientist. Student travel support for the meeting was requested from ARO, NSF, AFOSR, DOE, and NIST this year, and additional awards came from the DAMOP general fund. An approximate total of $38,000 was distributed in the form of student travel awards for the 2015 meeting.&nbs...
